So in the Latin inscription, see Introduction 2.8.2. This seems to be a popular rendition of the biblical name אסתר. It is not in keeping with LXX orthography (̓Εσθήρ – H & R Suppl. 62) or with Josephus’ tradition (̓Εσθήρα- Schalit, NB, 46). It does remind one, however, of the Greek name ̓Αστερία(WGE, 163) which means “star”. This name is recorded for Jews of Italy (e.g. CIJ, no. 94). The name ̓Αστήρ is also recorded for non-Jews (LGPN II, 76; III, 81). In those cases it is probably a male name. This could also be true for one case – ̓Αστήρ – recorded in CIJ, no. (306), but in all other cases the female gender is explicit in the Jewish inscriptions, like here, where it is linked with the female name [CL]AUDIA (and also CIJ, no. 213, 468, 579, 732, 733). Thus, perhaps as a female, it was a specifically Jewish name, identified with the Jewish queen. It should come as no surprise that this inscription is in Latin, since it was found in the Latin speaking world, although even in Rome, among Jews, Greek predominated ( H. J. Leon The Jews of Ancient Rome [Philadelphia 1960] 75-7). The form of the name in the Latin translations of the Bible, however, are Esther and Hester. The name אסתר in Semitic characters was not in use in Palestine during the Second Temple period, and came into use well after 70 CE, e.g Beth She‘arim1, 167 (in Palmyran characters); J. Naveh, “Aramaic Tombstones from Zoar,” Tarbiz 64 (1995) 479 (d. 416 CE), 492 (d. 468 CE); and on a Byzantine amulet AMB no. 13. It is therefore interesting to find the first instance of it in a woman who was born in Jerusalem before 70 CE but became a refugee in another country afterwards. Just as we may guess that this woman adopted the name Κλαυδια after her exile, we may also venture to suggest a similar history for Esther.

The name חנה was both male and female, see Introduction 1.5.2. As a male name it became somewhat more common in the centuries after the destruction, when Aramaic constructs became more frequent (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 263; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 498-500). As there is no sex indicator in this inscription, and as there were no bones found intact in the ossuary, the decision to identify this person as female is a somewhat random one. It is based on the ה rather than א ending which is the standard biblical spelling of the name of the prophet Samuel’s mother (e.g. 1 Sam. 1:2. It is, however, also the more common Palestinian, rather than Babylonian spelling), and on the fact that another female ossuary, that of Helene no. 2’s (הלנא with an א ending), decorated in the same fashion, was found nearby.

Perhaps in this family a unique orthographic tradition for this name was employed. Or else all three are not women. Although the popular name women bore in the Second Temple period was שלום, in modern Hebrew literature, one often finds the form שלומית instead (e.g. Simhoni’s translation of Salome, Herod’s sister, Salome no. 1, in Josephus’ BJ). The modern tradition probably stems from the name the Medieval Jossippon, (e.g. 146) gave to Herod’s sister, Salome no. 1.

The name שלום-Σαλώμη is the second most popular woman’s name during Second Temple times, see Introduction 1.1.2.1. It was certainly a woman’s (rather than a man’s) name and when found on ossuaries in the Hebrew form, שלום, denotes a name rather than a blessing (unlike in later inscriptions in Palestine and in contemporary Jewish inscriptions abroad -CIJ, no. 283, 293, 319, 597, 671 etc..
